items.title: What If Geography Is the Curriculum We Need for the Future?
items.summary: A geography teacher argues that the subject is essential for understanding systems of power, trade, and technology that shape our lives. By teaching students to see patterns and connections, geography can help them navigate a complex world and make informed decisions.
bullets: Geography teaches us not just where things are, but why they are there — and what could be otherwise.
It reveals how climate change doesn't 'affect us all equally,' but maps itself unevenly across lines of race, class, and power.
Students learn to navigate the world with agency by building tools that encourage them to see patterns, ask deeper questions, and connect classroom learning to their lived experiences.

overview.headline: Education News Roundup: Special Needs Services in Crisis, New College Rankings
overview.summary: A crisis is unfolding in England's special needs services as demand surges and resources dwindle. Meanwhile, a liberal arts college is embracing AI to enhance student learning, and public universities are calling for their own accreditor. In other news, California State University is embracing direct admissions, and Johns Hopkins is eliminating tuition for undergrads from low-income families.
